NEWS BITES

Ultra-Wealthy in the U.S. Are Selling Off Real Estate More Than They’re Buying It Amid fears of an upcoming recession, America’s ultra-rich are selling their luxury homes faster than they’re buying new ones. Tax changes are part of the reason for this trend, too, according to TD Wealth senior vice president and regional investment director James Beam. The general slowdown in this sector is causing price cuts at the high-end, leading mansions to be converted into rentals, and making sellers turn to tactics like throwing lavish parties to attract buyers. Business Insider

Middle Eastern Property Investors Prefer U.K. and U.S. Over the U.A.E. Despite the luxury and low-cost real estate options hitting the market in the U.A.E., Middle Eastern investors are still opting to invest in real estate in the U.S., the U.K. and continental Europe, according to Knight Frank. The U.K. has been the top location for Middle East investors for six to 10 years. The National

U.S. Home Flipping Slips to Eight-Year Low U.S. home flipping of single-family homes and condos in the second quarter of 2019 dropped 5.2% year-over-year to reach an eight-year low, according to ATTOM Data Solutions. Home flipping did increase from the previous quarter, however, by 12.4%. The total number of homes flipped in the second quarter reached 59,876. World Property Journal

Chinese Millionaires Deemed Responsible for Singapore’s 11-Year Luxury Home Sales High Millionaires from mainland China, seeking an alternative to Hong Kong, have propelled sales of luxury units in Singapore priced at S$10 million (US$7.3 million) or more, reaching an 11-year high, according to property consultants OrangeTee & Tie. Singapore, valued for its stability, sold 68 luxury units in the first eight months of this year. South China Morning Post

Tinder Co-Founder Sean Rad Relists Los Angeles Home For $9.75 Million Sean Rad, co-founder and former chairman of Tinder, listed his Hollywood Hills West home for $9.75 million after having it on the market last year for $10.9 million. He purchased the property for $7.65 million in 2016. The 5,600-square-foot home has five bedrooms and four-and-a-half bathrooms in addition to a swimming pool and a large motor court. Los Angeles Times
